questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to result from Streptococcus pyogenes?  (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scalded Skin Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSS) is caused by Staphylococcus aureus, not Streptococcus pyogenes. It is characterized by generalized erythema and tenderness of the skin, leading to the formation of bullae with light pressure (Nikolsky’s sign). SSS primarily affects children and immunocompromised adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Impetigo: A superficial skin infection commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes.

 

Option B. Erysipelas: An acute skin infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, leading to raised, well-demarcated, red areas.

 

Option C. Toxic shock syndrome: Can be caused by both Streptococcus pyogenes and Staphylococcus aureus, presenting with hypotension and multiorgan failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scalded Skin Syndrome is caused by Staphylococcus aureus and not by Streptococcus pyogenes.

questions.text: Where are lipid rafts typically observed? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Plasma membrane

 

Explanation:


Lipid rafts are specialized microdomains within the plasma membrane that are enriched in cholesterol and sphingolipids. These membrane regions serve as organizing centers for the assembly of signaling molecules and influence membrane fluidity and protein trafficking. When these rafts become infiltrated with caveolin protein, they form flask-shaped membrane depressions called caveolae ("little caves").

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Ribosomes - Ribosomes are cellular structures composed of RNA and protein that function as sites of protein synthesis. They lack the lipid bilayer structure necessary for lipid raft formation.
  • Option b. Mitochondria - While mitochondria have an inner and outer membrane, lipid rafts are specifically located in the cell membrane (plasma membrane), not in mitochondrial membranes.
  • Option d. ER - The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a membrane-bound organelle involved in protein synthesis and lipid metabolism. Though it contains membranes, lipid rafts are primarily identified and characterized in the plasma membrane.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lipid rafts are cholesterol and sphingolipid-rich microdomains in the plasma membrane that can develop into caveolae and play important roles in cellular signaling, cholesterol regulation, and transcytosis.

questions.text: A constant fraction of the filtered load is absorbed in the proximal tubule regardless of the value of the GFR. This is due to: NEET PG 2017
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomerulotubular feedback

 

Explanation: 

 

Glomerulotubular feedback refers to the mechanism by which a constant fraction of the filtered load of the nephron is reabsorbed across a range of glomerular filtration rates (GFR). When the GFR increases, the rate of reabsorption in the proximal tubule proportionally increases, maintaining the same fraction of the filtered load being reabsorbed. This balance ensures that changes in GFR do not lead to significant alterations in the amount of solute and water reabsorbed, stabilizing kidney function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubuloglomerular feedback: This mechanism helps maintain a stable GFR and renal blood flow by adjusting the arteriolar resistance based on the flow rate of the distal tubule, but it does not directly ensure a constant reabsorption fraction in the proximal tubule.

 

Option C. Glomerulo-glomerular feedback: This is not a recognized physiological mechanism related to reabsorption in the proximal tubule.

 

Option D. Tubulo-tubular feedback: This term is not commonly used in renal physiology and does not describe the mechanism responsible for maintaining a constant reabsorption fraction in the proximal tubule.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Glomerulotubular feedback ensures that a constant fraction of the nephron's filtered load is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, regardless of variations in GFR

choices.text: Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg

questions.text: All are components of CURB65 except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Systolic blood pressure less than 10mm Hg

 

The correct answer, D, specifies a systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg, which is not part of the CURB-65 criteria. The specified threshold for blood pressure in the CURB-65 is ≤90 mm Hg systolic or ≤60 mm Hg diastolic.

 

CURB-65 criteria is used to assess the severity of illness in case of pneumonia, especially community acquired pneumonia. It includes 5 variables -

 

C - Confusion

 

U - Urea>7mmol/L

 

R - Respiratory rate >30/mins

 

B - Blood pressure, SBP </=90 mmHg or diastolic </= 60 mmHg

 

65 - Age >/= 65 years

 

Management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CURB-65 scoring system is used to evaluate pneumonia severity, which does not include systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg but instead sets the threshold at ≤90 mm Hg systolic or ≤60 mm Hg diastolic.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is oxygen therapy not useful? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Central respiratory depression

 

Explanation 

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression, as oxygen therapy will reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe further depressing the respiratory frequency and minute ventilation.



 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Because oxygen therapy can be crucial in severe asthma attacks where it helps alleviate hypoxia.

 

Option B. Acute myocardial infarction: As oxygen therapy is often used to increase oxygen delivery to the heart tissue, reducing ischemic damage during an acute myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Pulmonary edema: Because oxygen therapy helps improve oxygenation in cases of pulmonary edema, especially if caused by heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression because it may reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe, potentially further depressing respiratory effort and overall ventilation.

questions.text: All of the following artery demonstrates Windkessel effect except: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial artery

 

Radial artery can show Windkessel effect, but among the given options, it is the most peripheral artery. As we move from center to periphery the elasticity property in the artery decreases, hence least Windkessel effect is seen in the radial artery hence it is the most appropriate answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Renal artery: The renal artery demonstrates the Windkessel effect due to its proximity to the aorta and its elastic properties.

 

Option C. Aorta: The aorta is a primary example of a vessel demonstrating the Windkessel effect.

 

Option D. Carotid artery:  The carotid artery also demonstrates the Windkessel effect due to its elastic properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINDKESSEL VESSELS

 

Large elastic arteries contain Elastin protein → elastic recoil

 

Ex: - Aorta & large arteries (e.g. Pulmonary Artery, Carotid, Renal artery)

 

  • During systole → Ventricle → eject blood → aorta gets stretched
  • During Diastole → Aortic recoil → DBP
  • At old age → Aortic stenosis → elasticity → hardening of aorta → SBP →DBP→PP

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Potassium

 

Explanation

 

Potassium is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.

 

Chemoreceptors are made up of two types of cells, type I or glomus cells and type II or sustentacular cells. Glomus cells have afferent nerve endings, which are stimulated by hypoxia. Type II cells are glial cells and provide support for type I cells.

 

Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels. Conductance of these channels is reduced proportionally to the degree of hypoxia resulting in K+ efflux → depolarization of cell and causes Ca+ influx →Excitation of afferent nerve ending.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium: Calcium is also involved but primarily in response to the depolarization initiated by changes in potassium ion conductance. It is not the initial ion involved in oxygen sensing.

 

Option C. Sodium: Sodium ions are not directly involved in the oxygen-sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Chlorine: Chlorine ions are not involved in the oxygen-sensing functions of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Potassium ions are crucial for the function of peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors, where they regulate the membrane potential and responsiveness of the cells to hypoxia. This process is vital for the body's ability to detect and respond to low oxygen levels, ensuring adequate oxygenation and cellular function.

choices.text: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing

questions.text: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mm Hg after 3 mins of standing

 

“3-20-10” mnemonic can aid in remembering the definition of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Sustained fall of SBP > 20mmHg /DBP > 10mmHg after 3 mins of standing. Usually, it is accompanied by a rise in HR. Absence of increase in heart rate suggest neurogenic/autonomic dysfunction.

 

Cause of Orthostatic Hypotension:

 

  • Cardiac pump failure
  • Hypovolemia
  • Endocrinopathies: AI, Pheochromocytoma.
  • Venous pooling
  • Medications

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and B: These options extend the timing to 6 minutes, which is not standard for the initial assessment of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Option D: Specifies a diastolic drop which should be 10 mmHg, not 20 mmHg, thus making it incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postural hypotension, also known as orthostatic hypotension, is defined as a significant drop in blood pressure when a person stands up from a sitting or lying position. The correct definition, as per the consensus, includes a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 20 mmHg or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg within 3 minutes of standing. The answer C correctly reflects the component of this definition regarding the systolic blood pressure drop.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology, chap 21/695

questions.text: The spinal trigeminal nucleus forms the second-order neuron of which of the following sensations? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus is located in the medulla and functions as a relay center, particularly for pain and temperature sensations from the face. It processes these sensations and transmits the information to higher brain centers for interpretation. The second-order neurons in the spinal trigeminal nucleus specifically relay pain and temperature information, making it a critical component in the sensory pathway for these modalities.

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus does not act as a relay center for other sensations like touch, two-point discrimination, or conscious proprioception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Touch: The sensation of touch is primarily processed through other pathways, such as the dorsal columns and the main sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, rather than the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Option C. Two-point discrimination: This sensation is typically processed by the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, not the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Option D. Conscious proprioception: Conscious proprioception is also processed via the dorsal columns, particularly through the cuneate and gracile nuclei, and not the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus in the medulla serves as the second-order neuron relay center specifically for pain and temperature sensations from the face.

choices.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less
Decreased release of 02
It has less P50
It is less acidic

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

 

Explanation

 

The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.

 

The ease with which hemoglobin releases oxygen to the tissues is controlled by erythrocytic 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) such that an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG decreases oxygen affinity and vice versa.

 

In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall, thus less oxygen is released to the tissues. Therefore, its use in hypoxic patients (E.g., anemia) is limited.

 

Phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine) prevents the fall in 2.3DPG levels. Higher 2,3 DPG concentration decreases affinity of Hb to the oxygen releasing oxygen to the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased release of O2: Incorrect. The goal of effective blood storage solutions like CPDA is to ensure that the oxygen release capacity is maintained, not decreased. CPDA helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG, which enhances the release of oxygen to tissues.

 

Option C. It has less P50: Incorrect. P50 is a measure of the oxygen tension at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated with oxygen. A higher P50, indicative of lower oxygen affinity, is preferable in stored blood as it means oxygen is more readily released to tissues—a trait supported by higher 2,3-DPG levels.

 

Option D. It is less acidic: Incorrect. While pH maintenance is important in blood storage, the primary benefit of CPDA over ACD is not related to less acidity but to its inclusion of phosphate and adenine, which help sustain energy (ATP) production and 2,3-DPG levels in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of CPDA in blood storage is superior to ACD due to its phosphate content, which helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG in stored red blood cells. This biochemical preservation is crucial for ensuring that transfused blood can effectively release oxygen to hypoxic tissues, making CPDA the preferred choice in clinical settings where blood transfusions are necessary.

questions.text: Which protein is primarily responsible for maintaining lateral alignment of adjacent myofibrils by connecting their Z-lines to each other? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Desmin

 

Desmin is an intermediate filament protein that plays a crucial role in maintaining the structural and mechanical integrity of muscle cells by connecting adjacent myofibrils at their Z-lines. This lateral connection is essential for proper force transmission and mechanical stability during muscle contraction. Desmin forms a three-dimensional scaffold around the myofibrillar Z-line, connecting neighboring myofibrils to each other and to the sarcolemma.

 

Key functions of desmin include:

  • Maintaining spatial organization of myofibrils
  • Ensuring synchronized contraction across the muscle fiber
  • Providing mechanical support to the contractile apparatus
  • Connecting myofibrils to various cellular organelles

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kinin: Incorrect as kinins are peptides involved in inflammation and vasodilation, not structural proteins of muscle fibers.

 

Option C. Titin: While titin is important for sarcomere structure, it runs longitudinally from Z-line to M-line within individual myofibrils and doesn't connect adjacent myofibrils to each other.

 

Option D. Actin: Though actin is a crucial contractile protein, it forms thin filaments within the sarcomere and isn't responsible for connecting adjacent myofibrils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the distinct roles of structural proteins in muscle architecture: While titin provides longitudinal stability within myofibrils, desmin is crucial for lateral alignment between myofibrils by connecting their Z-lines. This lateral connection is essential for coordinated muscle contraction and force transmission.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of milk production in the correct sequence: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

 

  1. Galactopoiesis
  2. Lactogenesis
  3. Mammogenesis
  4. Lactation
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 1, 4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence of milk production involves several stages, starting from the development of the mammary glands to the actual ejection of milk. These stages are:

 

3. Mammogenesis : This is the development of the mammary glands, which begins at birth but continues significantly during puberty. The breast tissue matures and prepares for potential milk production.

 

2. Lactogenesis : This stage refers to the initiation of milk synthesis. It involves hormonal changes that stimulate the mammary glands to start producing milk. Lactogenesis typically begins during the late stages of pregnancy and continues after childbirth.

 

1. Galactopoiesis : This is the maintenance of milk production after lactogenesis has initiated. It involves the continued synthesis and secretion of milk, which is essential for sustaining milk supply during breastfeeding.

 

4. Lactation: This refers to the process of milk ejection and feeding the baby. It encompasses the baby's suckling, which stimulates further milk production and ejection through the let-down reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of milk production involves mammogenesis, lactogenesis, galactopoiesis, and finally lactation.

choices.text: Increased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume
Decreased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume
Decreased lung volume, thoracic volume remains unaffected
Lung volume remains unaffected, Decreased thoracic volume

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented with right-sided rib pain and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray showed a significant right-sided pneumothorax with cardio-mediastinal shift to the left. Which of the following changes will be seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume

 

In a pneumothorax, air enters the pleural space, leading to a loss of negative pressure that normally keeps the lung inflated. This causes the affected lung to collapse, significantly decreasing its volume. Concurrently, the thoracic cavity compensates by expanding due to the increase in pressure within the pleural space. This expansion is often accompanied by a mediastinal shift towards the unaffected side, in this case, the left side, as seen in the X-ray. The increase in thoracic volume occurs as the chest wall expands outward due to the absence of opposing forces from the collapsed lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume: This option is incorrect because in pneumothorax, the lung volume decreases due to collapse, not increases.

 

Option C. Decreased lung volume, thoracic volume remains unaffected: This is incorrect because, although lung volume decreases, the thoracic volume typically increases as the pleural cavity expands.

 

Option D. Lung volume remains unaffected, Decreased thoracic volume: This is incorrect because pneumothorax leads to a decrease in lung volume and an increase in thoracic volume, not a decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pneumothorax, the affected lung collapses leading to decreased lung volume, while the thoracic volume increases due to the loss of negative pleural pressure and the expansion of the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: Identify the site which is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Periaqueductal gray

 

The analgesia system consists of three major components:

 

(1) The periaqueductal gray and periventricular areas of the mesencephalon and upper pons surround the aqueduct of Sylvius and portions of the third and fourth ventricles. Neurons from these areas send signals to  

 

(2) the raphe magnus nucleus, a thin midline nucleus located in the lower pons and upper medulla, and the nucleus reticularis paragigantocellularis, located laterally in the medulla. From these nuclei, second-order signals are transmitted down the dorsolateral columns in the spinal cord to

 

(3) a pain inhibitory complex located in the dorsal horns of the spinal cord. At this point, the analgesia signals can block the pain before it is relayed to the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticospinal tract: Incorrect. This tract is involved in motor control and voluntary movements, not pain relief.

 

Option C. Medial lemniscus: Incorrect. This pathway carries sensory information related to touch, vibration, and proprioception, not pain relief.

 

Option D. Medial longitudinal fasciculus: Incorrect. This bundle of nerve fibers coordinates eye movements and helps maintain balance, not pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a critical component of the analgesia system, responsible for relieving pain by sending inhibitory signals to block pain transmission in the spinal cord.

questions.text: Which channel opens when action potential begins? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Na+ influx

 

The initiation of an action potential in a neuron begins with the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels. When a neuron receives a sufficient threshold stimulus, these sodium channels open, allowing Na+ ions to flow into the cell. This influx of positive sodium ions causes the membrane potential to become more positive, a process known as depolarization.

 

Depolarization is the first phase of the action potential, which is essential for the propagation of electrical signals along the neuron. Following depolarization, the action potential continues with other ion movements that facilitate the signal's transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cl- influx: Chloride ions typically move into the cell during inhibitory postsynaptic potentials, causing hyperpolarization (making the inside of the cell more negative). This is not related to the initiation of action potentials.

 

Option C. K+ efflux: Potassium efflux occurs during the repolarization phase of the action potential, not at the beginning. Repolarization helps restore the resting membrane potential after depolarization.

 

Option D. Ca2+ influx: Calcium influx is crucial in various cellular processes, such as neurotransmitter release at synapses. However, it is not involved in the initial depolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initiation of an action potential in a neuron is marked by the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels, leading to Na+ influx and membrane depolarization.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

 

Option B. Globin part of hemoglobin: 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Globin part of myoglobin: 2,3-BPG does not bind to myoglobin. Myoglobin, primarily found in muscle tissue, has a higher affinity for oxygen and does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. Heme part of myoglobin: The heme part of myoglobin binds to oxygen directly; 2,3-BPG does not bind to this site or affect myoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option D. Heme part of hemoglobin: While the heme part of hemoglobin is the site for oxygen binding, 2,3-BPG does not bind here. It binds at a separate site on the globin chains to modulate oxygen affinity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

questions.text: The image shows changes in membrane potential during an action potential. The region marked between 4 to 5 is due to?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Efflux of K+

 

The action potential curve shows the different phases of an action potential in a neuron. The region marked between 4 and 5 corresponds to repolarization and hyperpolarization.

 

  • Phase 4 to 5 (Repolarization and Hyperpolarization): During this phase, voltage-gated potassium channels remain open, and there is an efflux of K+ ions from the cell, causing the membrane potential to return to the resting level or even become more negative (hyperpolarization).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Influx of Na+: This occurs during the depolarization phase (Phase 0 to 1), not during repolarization.

 

Option B. Efflux of Na+: This does not occur in the action potential phases.

 

Option C. Influx of K+: Potassium ions typically move out of the cell (efflux) during repolarization, not into the cell.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which ion's concentration change has the most significant effect on the excitability of cells through RMP? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. K+

 

Explanation:


Potassium (K+) concentration changes have the most significant impact on cellular excitability. The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by K+ gradients across the membrane. In mild to moderate hyperkalemia, the decreased concentration gradient results in less K+ moving outward, leading to depolarization and increased excitability. Conversely, hypokalemia causes hyperpolarization, moving the membrane potential further from threshold and decreasing excitability.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. Na+ - While sodium is essential for action potential generation, changes in external Na+ concentration primarily affect the amplitude of action potentials rather than the resting membrane potential. Na+ has little effect on the baseline excitability of cells.
  • Option c. Cl- - Chloride primarily influences inhibitory post-synaptic potentials through influx causing hyperpolarization. Its concentration changes affect modulation of neuronal responses but don't have the most significant effect on baseline cellular excitability.
  • Option d. Ca+2 - Calcium functions as a membrane stabilizing agent. Hypocalcemia increases excitability by decreasing the depolarization threshold needed to initiate action potentials, while hypercalcemia decreases excitability. However, these effects are not as profound as potassium's direct influence on the resting potential.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Potassium concentration directly determines the resting membrane potential, establishing the baseline excitability state of neurons and muscle cells, making K+ the ion whose concentration changes most significantly affect cellular excitability.

questions.text: Which phenomenon is regulated by the Gibbs-Donnan effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chloride Shift

 

Explanation:

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect fundamentally influences the behavior of charged particles across semi-permeable membranes, leading to unequal distribution due to immobile ions on one side of the membrane. This principle is critical in explaining the Chloride Shift, also known as the Hamburger phenomenon, which occurs in red blood cells. During the Chloride Shift, bicarbonate ions (HCO3−) generated from the conversion of carbon dioxide to carbonic acid move out of red blood cells into the plasma. To maintain electrical neutrality, chloride ions (Cl−) move from the plasma into the red blood cells. This ion exchange is facilitated by the Gibbs-Donnan effect, which governs the distribution of ions across the membrane, thereby impacting the movement and balance of ions during the Chloride Shift.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bohr Effect: Incorrect as the Bohr Effect involves the influence of carbon dioxide and pH on the oxygen-binding capacity of hemoglobin, unrelated to the ion distribution described by the Gibbs-Donnan effect.

 

Option C. Haldane Effect: Incorrect because the Haldane Effect refers to the increased ability of deoxygenated blood to carry carbon dioxide, which is not directly related to membrane ion distribution.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as the Gibbs-Donnan effect directly governs the Chloride Shift.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect is used in regulating the Chloride Shift in red blood cells, where it controls the exchange of bicarbonate and chloride ions across the cell membrane to maintain electrical and osmotic balance.

choices.text: AIDP with migraine
Right side paralysis
Acute intermittent porphyria
Conversion disorder

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient came with complaints of vomiting and a decrease in movement of the right leg. In the past, she has had episodes of violent and aggressive behavior and abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute intermittent porphyria

 

Vomiting & decreased movements of right leg in young female with previous history of abdominal pain and mental symptoms like violent and aggressive behavior points towards acute intermittent porphyria.

 

Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder.

 

It is due to deficiency of HMB Synthase enzyme.

 

ACUTE INTERMITTENT PORPHYRIA

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Common precipitating factors include endogenous and exogeneous steroids, porphyrinogenic drugs, alcohol ingestion and low-calorie diets, usually instituted for weight loss.
  • Symptoms are more common in women, suggesting a role for estrogens or progestins.
  • Abdominal pain, the most common symptom is usually steady and poorly localized but maybe cramping.
  • Nausea, vomiting, constipation, tachycardia hypertension, mental symptoms, pain in the limbs, head, neck or chest, muscle weakness, sensory loss, dysuria, and urinary retention are characteristic.
  • The peripheral neuropathy is due to neurologic axonal degeneration (rather than demyelination) and primarily affects motor neurons.
  • Mental symptoms such as anxiety, insomnia, depression, disorientation, hallucination and paranoia can occur in acute attacks.
  • Seizures can be due to neurologic effects or to hyponatremia (due to hypothalamic involvement and inappropriate vasopressin secretion or from electrolyte depletion due to vomiting, diarrhea, poor intake or excess renal sodium loss).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • ALA & PBG levels are substantially increased in plasma and urine, especially during acute attacks.

 

Treatment:

 

  • I.V. Hemin is more effective and should be used as first line therapy for all acute attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AIDP with migraine: Incorrect because AIDP (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy) presents with rapid onset muscle weakness and decreased reflexes, not specifically associated with vomiting or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Right side paralysis: Incorrect as this diagnosis does not account for the broader spectrum of symptoms including behavioral changes and abdominal pain.

 

Option D. Conversion disorder: Incorrect because conversion disorder involves symptoms that suggest neurological or medical conditions but are actually manifestations of psychological conflict or needs. The specific clinical presentation and past medical history in this case strongly point towards a physiological rather than psychological cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The acute intermittent porphyria presents with a complex array of symptoms, including neurological, gastrointestinal, and psychiatric manifestations, and is associated with specific triggers and a genetic basis. Elevated ALA and PBG levels during attacks are diagnostic.

choices.text: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.text: Brown Sequard syndrome is characterized by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome results from a hemisection (partial transection) of the spinal cord, leading to a distinct pattern of neurological symptoms:

 

  • Ipsilateral (same side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Motor Function: There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
    • Proprioception and Discriminative Touch: Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain.
  • Contralateral (opposite side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Pain and Temperature Sensation: Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fine touch lost on the opposite side: Incorrect because fine touch is lost on the same side as the lesion, not the opposite.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature lost on the same side: Incorrect as pain and temperature sensations are lost on the opposite side due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option D. Only pain lost on the same side: Incorrect because pain sensation is lost on the opposite side and is associated with temperature loss as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemi section of the spinal cord involves the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Sequard syndrome.

 

 

Functions of tracts involved -

 

Fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus → ipsilateral discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception

 

Spinothalamic tract → contralateral pain and temperature sensation

 

Corticospinal tract → primary motor activity same side of the body.

questions.text: Which GLUT is present in the skeletal muscle, adipose tissue? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) GLUT 4

 

Explanation:


GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter primarily found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. It is an insulin-dependent glucose transporter, meaning that its activity is stimulated by insulin. This allows for the efficient uptake of glucose into cells in response to insulin, helping to regulate blood sugar levels.

 

  • GLUT 2 is insulin-independent and is found in the liver, beta cells of the pancreas, intestines, and kidneys. It helps in the regulation of insulin and plays a key role in glucose sensing.
  • GLUT 5 is primarily involved in fructose transport and is found in the small intestine, kidney, and sperm.
  • GLUT 1 is a ubiquitous glucose transporter found in most tissues, including the brain, erythrocytes, and endothelial cells of the blood-brain barrier. It is responsible for the basal glucose uptake necessary for cellular metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT 2: As stated, GLUT 2 is insulin-independent and is not primarily involved in glucose uptake in skeletal muscle or adipose tissue.

 

Option C. GLUT 5: This transporter is primarily for fructose, not glucose, and is found in the small intestine and other locations, not in skeletal muscle or adipose tissue.

 

Option D. GLUT 1: Although present in many tissues, GLUT 1 is not the primary glucose transporter for skeletal muscle and adipose tissue, which rely on insulin-dependent GLUT 4 for glucose uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT 4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter present in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue.

questions.text: In a premature infant with respiratory distress syndrome, which component was found to be significantly elevated in the pulmonary surfactant analysis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sphingomyelin

 

Explanation:

 

  • In respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), there is a characteristic alteration in the composition of pulmonary surfactant, most notably an elevation in sphingomyelin levels relative to other components.
  • This elevation is clinically significant as it leads to an abnormally low lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio, which is a key diagnostic indicator of pulmonary immaturity.
  • Normal mature lungs have an L/S ratio ≥ 2:1, indicating higher levels of lecithin (DPPC) compared to sphingomyelin.
  • In RDS, the L/S ratio is typically < 1.5:1, reflecting both decreased DPPC and increased sphingomyelin levels.
  • Clinical relevance - An elevated sphingomyelin level combined with decreased DPPC is a more sensitive indicator of lung immaturity than measuring DPPC deficiency alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine: Incorrect. DPPC is actually decreased in RDS, not elevated. It is the primary surfactant component that is deficient in this condition.

 

Option C. Phosphatidylglycerol: Incorrect. Phosphatidylglycerol is typically decreased in immature lungs and RDS, not elevated. Its presence in amniotic fluid is actually used as a marker of fetal lung maturity.

 

Option D. Palmitic acid: Incorrect. While palmitic acid is a component of surfactant, its levels are not characteristically elevated in RDS. It is primarily incorporated into DPPC, which is decreased in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the inverse relationship between sphingomyelin and DPPC levels in RDS is crucial for interpreting L/S ratios and assessing fetal lung maturity. This relationship forms the basis for using the L/S ratio as a diagnostic tool in predicting RDS risk in premature infants.

choices.text: Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.
Apoferritin is the storage form.
Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood.
Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

 

Iron metabolism involves complex processes where iron must be in the correct oxidation state to be absorbed and utilized effectively by the body. Iron in the diet is primarily found in the ferric (Fe3+) form, but for it to be absorbed across the apical membrane of enterocytes in the intestine, it needs to be converted into the ferrous (Fe2+) form. This conversion is crucial because only ferrous iron can be effectively transported into the cells. The statement in option A is incorrect because it suggests the opposite process—conversion from ferrous to ferric—before absorption, which is not accurate. The conversion actually goes from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) before iron is absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoferritin is the storage form: This statement is correct. Apoferritin binds with iron to form ferritin, which is the storage form of iron within cells.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood: This is also correct. After iron is absorbed into the bloodstream, it binds to the protein transferrin, which transports it to various tissues, including the bone marrow for hemoglobin production.

 

Option D. Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption: This statement is true. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) reduces ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which enhances its absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron must be converted from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) form for effective absorption through the apical membrane of enterocytes

questions.text: How muscle spindle able to detect the length while muscle is contracting? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nuclear bag fibers

 

Muscle spindles are sensory receptors within the muscle that detect changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length. They consist of intrafusal fibers, which include both nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers.

 

These fibers are dynamic and are sensitive to the rate of change in muscle length (velocity of stretch). They play a crucial role in detecting muscle length changes during muscle contraction by responding to the speed at which the muscle length is changing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nuclear chain fibers: These fibers are more static and respond to the absolute length of the muscle rather than the rate of change. They are not primarily responsible for detecting changes during contraction.

 

Option C. Golgi tendon organ: This sensory receptor is located at the junction of the muscle and tendon. It monitors tension rather than length changes in the muscle. It is more involved in preventing muscle damage due to excessive force.

 

Option D. Other muscle receptor: This option is too vague. The specific receptor responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during contraction is the nuclear bag fiber.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuclear bag fibers in the muscle spindle are responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during muscle contraction, making them essential for proprioception and motor control.

questions.text: What is the value of normal Glomerular oncotic pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 32 mmHg

 

The value of normal Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure is 32 mmHg.

 

Oncotic pressure, or colloid osmotic-pressure, is a form of osmotic pressure induced by the proteins, notably albumin, in a blood vessel's plasma (blood/liquid. that causes a pull-on fluid back into the capillary. Participating colloids displace water molecules, thus creating a relative water molecule deficit with water molecules moving back into the circulatory system within the lower venous pressure end of capillaries.

 

It is mostly negligible, but sometimes can be as high as 6 mmHg in the brain. The values are also positive in the liver and kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal glomerular oncotic pressure is approximately 32 mmHg, which helps maintain fluid balance by drawing water back into the capillaries.

choices.text: Nernst potential for Cl– is –90 mV

questions.text: Which statement is true about the Nernst equation? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Used to calculate equilibrium potential

 

Explanation:


The Nernst equation is fundamentally used to calculate the equilibrium potential for individual ions across a cell membrane. The equation expresses the relationship between the equilibrium potential (E) of an ion and its concentration gradient across the membrane. This mathematical tool determines the membrane potential at which the electrical gradient exactly balances the concentration gradient for a specific ion, resulting in no net movement of that ion.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. Calculated for non-ionic solutions - The Nernst equation specifically applies to ions and ionic solutions, not non-ionic solutions. It calculates the potential difference created by concentration differences of specific charged particles.
  • Option c. Nernst potential for Cl– is –90 mV - This is incorrect. The equilibrium potential for Cl- in mammalian spinal neurons is approximately -70 mV, not -90 mV. The value of -90 mV is actually the equilibrium potential for K+ ions.
  • Option d. All are correct - This cannot be true as options b and c contain incorrect information.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Nernst equation is a fundamental tool in cell physiology that calculates the equilibrium potential for a specific ion across a membrane, representing the electrical potential at which diffusional and electrical forces acting on that ion are in balance.

questions.text: In the presence of elevated ADH levels, which part of the renal tubule reabsorbs the most water? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Proximal tubule

 

Explanation: 

 

The proximal tubule reabsorbs the largest percentage of filtered water (60-70%) even in the presence of ADH (vasopressin). This represents obligatory H₂O reabsorption that occurs regardless of hormonal status. The Loop of Henle handles 10-15% of water reabsorption, while the distal tubule and collecting ducts account for the remaining reabsorption, which is regulated by ADH as facultative H₂O reabsorption.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Loop of Henle - Only reabsorbs 10-15% of filtered water, significantly less than the proximal tubule. Water reabsorption here occurs primarily in the descending limb due to the presence of aquaporin-1 channels.
  • Option C. Distal tubule - Reabsorbs only 1-3% of water without ADH and up to 10-15% with ADH, still considerably less than the proximal tubule.
  • Option D. Collecting duct - While ADH has its most significant effect here (making it critical for concentrating urine), the absolute amount of water reabsorbed is less than in the proximal tubule. Approximately 14.7% total water reabsorption occurs in the collecting ducts (10% in cortical + 4.7% in medullary collecting ducts).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The proximal tubule performs the majority of water reabsorption (60-70%) through obligatory mechanisms independent of ADH, while ADH primarily regulates the facultative water reabsorption in the distal segments of the nephron.

choices.text: 35 days and 42 days
21 days and 35 days
28 days and 45 days
35 days and 28 days

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct storage period when phosphate added to acid citrate dextrose (ACD) and when phosphate and adenine together added to ACD: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 21 days and 35 days

 

Explanation

 

The storage period when adding phosphate alone to ACD would be 21 days and when adding adenine and phosphate together would be 35 days.

 

ACD was developed into CPD (citrate-phosphate-dextrose) version with phosphate added intended to reduce phosphate leakage from red blood cells. It does not improve shelf life appreciably, but patient recovery is improved.

 

CPD with adenine (CPDA-1), which boosted RBC survival by improving ATP synthesis of RBCs to five weeks when combined with plastic bags.

 

CPD, in combination with adenine-mannitol additives such as SAGM, is the current blood bank preservative as of 2012.

 

RBC hemolysis, thus increasing the storage period to 42 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphate alone added to ACD allows for a blood storage period of 21 days, while the addition of both phosphate and adenine (as in CPDA-1) extends the storage period to 35 days, reflecting improvements in RBC viability through enhanced ATP synthesis.

questions.text: A mother comes to the hospital with her newborn baby. On examination, surfactants are not adequately found and collapse of alveoli was seen. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory distress syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a condition commonly seen in premature infants where the lungs are not fully developed, leading to a deficiency in surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, allowing them to remain open and facilitating proper gas exchange. Without adequate surfactant, the alveoli collapse, leading to impaired gas exchange and difficulty breathing, which is the hallmark of RDS. In this case, the mother's newborn shows signs of inadequate surfactant and alveolar collapse, making RDS the most probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: This condition involves chronic inflammation of the airways, typically seen in older children and adults, not newborns. It presents with symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath but is not associated with surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse.

 

Option C. Pneumonia: This is an infection of the lungs that can cause fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. While it can affect newborns, it does not involve surfactant deficiency or the collapse of alveoli.

 

Option D. Pleural effusion: This condition involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space around the lungs. It can cause breathing difficulties but is not related to surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily due to a lack of surfactant, leading to alveolar collapse and breathing difficulties.

questions.text: Which receptor on the sarcoplasmic reticulum directly interacts with voltage-gated calcium channels during skeletal muscle contraction? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ryanodine receptor

 

Explanation:

 

The excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle involves a direct mechanical coupling between two key proteins:

 

  1. Ryanodine receptor (RyR): 
    • Located on the sarcoplasmic reticulum
    • Physically interacts with dihydropyridine receptors (DHPRs) on T-tubules
    • This mechanical coupling allows direct calcium release without requiring calcium influx through DHPRs
    • Critical for rapid and efficient muscle contraction
  2. The interaction between RyR and DHPR is unique to skeletal muscle and differs from cardiac muscle, where calcium-induced calcium release occurs instead of direct mechanical coupling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IP3 receptor: Incorrect. While IP3 receptors are calcium channels found on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, they are not involved in skeletal muscle excitation-contraction coupling. They are more important in smooth muscle contraction.

 

Option B. SERCA pump: Incorrect. SERCA is responsible for pumping calcium back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum during muscle relaxation but does not interact with voltage-gated calcium channels during contraction.

 

Option D. Nicotinic receptor: Incorrect. These receptors are found at the neuromuscular junction and respond to acetylcholine. They do not directly interact with voltage-gated calcium channels in the excitation-contraction coupling process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the unique mechanical coupling between ryanodine receptors and dihydropyridine receptors in skeletal muscle is crucial for comprehending how electrical signals are converted to mechanical responses without requiring calcium entry through DHPRs, unlike in cardiac muscle.

choices.text: Concentration of K+ is greater in ECF
Concentration of Cl– is greater in ICF
Total ions are more in ICF

questions.text: As a result of the Donnan-Gibbs effect, which of the following is true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Total ions are more in ICF

 

Explanation:


The Donnan-Gibbs effect describes the unequal distribution of ions across a semipermeable membrane when one ion (typically charged proteins) cannot cross the membrane. In cells, the non-diffusible ions are primarily the negatively charged proteins (Prot-) trapped inside. This creates an electrical imbalance that affects the distribution of all permeable ions, ultimately resulting in more total osmotically active particles (ions) inside the cell than outside. This ion imbalance contributes to the osmotic pressure that would make cells swell and potentially rupture if not counterbalanced by the Na, K ATPase pump.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Concentration of K+ is greater in ECF - This is false. K+ concentration is significantly higher in the intracellular fluid (approximately 140 mEq/L) compared to extracellular fluid (approximately 4.5 mEq/L). The Donnan effect actually contributes to this concentration difference.
  • Option b. Concentration of Cl– is greater in ICF - Cl- is higher in ECF than in ICF, it is not the primary consequence of the Donnan-Gibbs effect. The key result is the overall ionic imbalance with more total ions in ICF.
  • Option d. All are true - This cannot be correct since option a is false.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Donnan-Gibbs equilibrium results in an asymmetric distribution of ions across cell membranes with more total ions accumulating in the intracellular compartment due to the presence of non-diffusible, negatively charged proteins.

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Late distal tubule and collecting duct

questions.text: In a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus, which part of the tubule would have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Late distal tubule and collecting duct

 

In central diabetes insipidus, there is a deficiency of ADH (vasopressin) secretion from the posterior pituitary. Without ADH, the collecting ducts become relatively impermeable to water. This causes the already dilute fluid entering from the distal tubule to remain hypotonic without the normal water reabsorption that would concentrate it. In diabetes insipidus, urine osmolality can be extremely low (50-100 mOsm/L) due to this lack of water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Proximal tubule - Incorrect because proximal tubular fluid remains essentially iso-osmotic with plasma (around 300 mOsm/kg) regardless of ADH status. About 60-70% of filtered water is reabsorbed here through aquaporin-1 channels that function independently of ADH.
  • Option B. Descending limb of the loop of Henle - Incorrect because tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment as water moves out via aquaporin-1 channels into the hypertonic medullary interstitium. ADH status does not significantly affect this segment.
  • Option C. Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle - Incorrect because while this segment does create hypotonic fluid by actively transporting Na+, K+, and Cl- out of the tubule without water (it's water-impermeable), the tubular fluid becomes even more dilute as it continues through the distal tubule and collecting duct in the absence of ADH.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The late distal tubule and collecting duct display the lowest tubular fluid osmolality in central diabetes insipidus because these segments, which normally concentrate urine under ADH influence, remain impermeable to water without ADH, allowing maximally dilute fluid to be excreted.

questions.text: A team of climbers is being briefed about the physiological changes that occur in the body at high altitudes. Which of the following is NOT a typical physiological response seen in individuals at high altitudes?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoventilation is not a typical response at high altitude. In fact, the opposite occurs - hyperventilation, or increased breathing rate, is a normal physiological response to high altitude to compensate for reduced oxygen availability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polycythemia: Polycythemia, an increase in the number of red blood cells, is a common response to high altitude. It occurs as a compensatory mechanism to improve oxygen carrying capacity due to lower oxygen availability in the atmosphere.

 

Option B. Increase in Hemoglobin (Hb) concentration: An increase in hemoglobin concentration is also a typical response to high altitude. This adaptation helps to enhance the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Option C. Increase in myoglobin: There is an increase in myoglobin in muscle tissues at high altitudes. Myoglobin helps in storing oxygen in muscle cells, aiding adaptation to the lower oxygen environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At high altitudes, physiological responses include polycythemia, increased hemoglobin concentration, and increased myoglobin, but not hypoventilation.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central inhibition: Incorrect. Central inhibition is not the primary mechanism of action for TENS in pain relief.

 

Option B. Desensitization: Incorrect. Desensitization refers to a reduction in response to a stimulus over time, which is not the primary mechanism for TENS.

 

Option D. Descending inhibition: Incorrect. While descending inhibitory pathways are involved in the modulation of pain, the gate control theory specifically explains the mechanism behind TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) reduces pain through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large diameter afferent fibers.

choices.text: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
Rigidity is pronounced
It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.text: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

 

Explanation

 

Decorticate animal is the one without cerebral cortex.

 

In man, decorticate condition is caused by intracranial hemorrhage, head injury, brain abscess or brain tumor. Decorticate condition is called decorticate rigidity

 

Decorticate rigidity is the abnormal postural changes that involve rigid extension of the lower limbs and flexion of the upper limbs at elbow joint across the chest. Wrists and fingers are also flexed. Posture may develop on one side or both sides of the body.

 

Reflexes at the neck level can be elicited

 

  • When the neck is turned to right, there is flexion of the lower and upper limbs on the opposite side. But, on the same side, there is extension of the limbs.
  • It may be due to the cutting or lesion of direct corticospinal tract. Some fibers of corticospinal tract are known to have inhibitory influence on the extensor muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia: Incorrect as decorticate rigidity typically does not involve the removal of the basal ganglia.

 

Option B. Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs: Incorrect as this describes a reverse of the decorticate rigidity posturing.

 

Option C. Rigidity is pronounced: This statement is somewhat vague but could be considered true in the context of how muscle rigidity is indeed pronounced in decorticate rigidity. However, it does not specifically describe the characteristic posture associated with decorticate rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs, often occurring in response to severe brain damage above the midbrain level. It is a distinctive postural manifestation of significant central nervous system disruption.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adipose tissue

 

Adipose tissue is dependent on insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Insulin stimulates glucose uptake into adipose tissue, promoting the storage of excess glucose as triglycerides in fat cells, thus regulating energy storage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain: The brain is capable of taking up glucose independent of insulin due to the presence of glucose transporter proteins that are insulin-independent, such as GLUT1. The brain has a high energy demand and relies heavily on glucose as its primary fuel source.

 

Option C. Pancreas: The pancreas does not take up significant amounts of glucose because its primary function is to produce and secrete insulin itself, among other hormones.

 

Option D. Kidney: The kidneys have glucose transporters, but they play a role in reabsorbing glucose from the urine back into the bloodstream rather than being dependent on insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adipose tissue is dependent on insulin for glucose uptake, which facilitates the storage of glucose as triglycerides in fat cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a chronic productive cough and progressive difficulty in breathing. On examination, his FEV1% is significantly reduced. Based on this finding, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) COPD

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by chronic airflow limitation that is not fully reversible. It is commonly associated with a history of smoking and is diagnosed based on symptoms such as chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and a significant reduction in FEV1%. The airflow obstruction in COPD is due to a combination of airway disease (chronic bronchitis) and parenchymal destruction (emphysema), leading to difficulty in exhaling air from the lungs.

 

In this case, the patient presents with a chronic productive cough and progressive difficulty in breathing, which are hallmark symptoms of COPD. The significant reduction in FEV1% further supports the diagnosis of an obstructive lung disease, where the primary issue is the narrowing of the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary Fibrosis - Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease characterized by the stiffening and scarring of lung tissue, which makes it difficult for the lungs to expand. FEV1% is typically preserved or increased in restrictive lung diseases, not significantly reduced as seen in obstructive lung diseases like COPD.

 

Option C. Asthma - While asthma is also an obstructive lung disease, it is usually characterized by reversible airway obstruction and presents with intermittent episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and dry cough. Chronic productive cough is less common in asthma compared to COPD.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis - Sarcoidosis is a multi-system inflammatory disease that primarily affects the lungs but presents with a variety of other systemic symptoms. It is more commonly associated with a restrictive pattern on lung function tests and does not typically present with a chronic productive cough or a significantly reduced FEV1% as seen in COPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a chronic productive cough, progressive difficulty in breathing, and a significant reduction in FEV1%. It is a common cause of chronic obstructive pulmonary symptoms in older adults, particularly those with a history of smoking.

choices.text: It moves against the concentration gradient

questions.text: Which statement is true about facilitated diffusion? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. It requires a carrier

 

Explanation:

 

Facilitated diffusion is a form of passive transport that requires specific carrier proteins to move substances across the cell membrane. These carrier proteins bind molecules and then change their configuration, facilitating the movement of the bound substance across the membrane. This type of transport is characterized by several key properties: it requires specific carrier proteins, exhibits saturation kinetics, shows specificity for the transported substance, and can demonstrate competition between similar molecules for the same carrier.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. It is active - False. Facilitated diffusion is classified as passive transport, not active transport. It moves substances down their concentration or electrical gradient without requiring energy input.
  • Option c. It requires ATP - False. Unlike primary active transport, facilitated diffusion does not require ATP or other energy sources. The movement occurs due to the existing concentration gradient.
  • Option d. It moves against the concentration gradient - False. Facilitated diffusion only moves substances down their concentration gradient (from high to low concentration), never against it. Moving substances against their concentration gradient requires active transport mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Facilitated diffusion is a passive transport process requiring specific carrier proteins (such as GLUT for glucose) that enables the movement of substances down their concentration gradient across cell membranes at a faster rate than would occur by simple diffusion alone.

questions.text: How can total body fat be estimated accurately? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Hydrostatic Weighing

 

Explanation:


Hydrostatic weighing is considered the gold standard method for estimating total body fat. This technique measures body density by weighing a person both on land and while completely submerged in water. Since fat tissue is less dense than lean tissue, the overall body density can be used to calculate the percentage of body fat accurately. This method follows similar principles to those used in fluid volume estimation through displacement measurements.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Waist-Hip ratio - This measurement estimates fat distribution pattern (central versus peripheral) rather than total body fat percentage. It indicates risk for certain diseases but is not an accurate measure of total body fat content.
  • Option C. Body mass index - BMI is calculated from height and weight (kg/m²) and provides a general estimate of body composition. However, it doesn't distinguish between fat mass and lean mass, making it unreliable for accurate total body fat estimation, especially in athletes with high muscle mass.
  • Option D. Total body calcium - This measurement relates primarily to bone mineral density assessment, not body fat estimation. Total body calcium correlates with lean body mass rather than fat mass, making it unsuitable for total body fat determination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hydrostatic weighing provides the most accurate estimation of total body fat by determining body density through the displacement of water when submerged, allowing precise calculation of fat percentage.

choices.text: Ito cells
Endothelial cells

questions.text: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ito cells

 

Explanation

 

  • Ito cells are the cells that store vitamin A in the liver. These cells, also known as hepatic stellate cells, are located in the space of Disse, which is between the hepatocytes and the endothelial cells in the liver.
  • Ito cells play a role in liver function and pathology, and are involved in the regulation of extracellular matrix synthesis and degradation, as well as in the response to liver injury. They are also responsible for the storage and release of vitamin A in the liver.
  • Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatocytes: Incorrect, while hepatocytes are the main functional cells of the liver and perform numerous metabolic, synthetic, and detoxifying functions, they are not the primary storage sites for vitamin A.

 

Option C. Endothelial cells: Incorrect, these cells line the blood vessels of the liver and are involved in filtration and blood flow regulation within the organ, not in vitamin storage.

 

Option D. Kupffer cells: Incorrect, Kupffer cells are the liver's resident macrophages, involved in immune responses and the breakdown of red blood cells, not in storing vitamins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ito cells (hepatic stellate cells) are the primary storage sites for vitamin A in the liver. Their role extends beyond vitamin storage to include critical functions in the regulation of the extracellular matrix and the liver's response to injury.

choices.text: Acts as a negative regulator of iron absorption
Binds to ferroportin causing its internalization
Increases serum iron levels by promoting iron release from cells
Production increases in response to high iron levels

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about hepcidin's role in iron homeostasis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increases serum iron levels by promoting iron release from cells

 

Hepcidin is a key regulatory hormone in iron homeostasis. It functions as a negative regulator by binding to ferroportin, the only known cellular iron exporter. When hepcidin binds to ferroportin, it causes its internalization and degradation, thereby reducing iron export from cells. This leads to decreased serum iron levels by preventing iron release from enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acts as a negative regulator of iron absorption: This is correct. By causing ferroportin degradation in enterocytes, hepcidin reduces dietary iron absorption.

 

Option B. Binds to ferroportin causing its internalization: This is correct. The binding of hepcidin to ferroportin triggers its internalization and subsequent lysosomal degradation.

 

Option D. Production increases in response to high iron levels: This is correct. Elevated iron levels stimulate hepcidin production through the BMP-SMAD pathway, creating a negative feedback loop to prevent iron overload.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding hepcidin's central role in systemic iron homeostasis through its ability to reduce iron absorption and release from cells by targeting ferroportin for degradation, thereby preventing iron overload.

questions.text: Which among the following organs has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kidney

 

The arteriovenous oxygen difference (A-V O2 difference) is a measure of the amount of oxygen extracted by the tissues from the blood. The greater the oxygen utilization by the tissues, the larger the A-V O2 difference.

 

  • Kidney: The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference. This is because the primary function of the kidneys is to filter large volumes of blood through the glomeruli rather than to metabolize oxygen extensively. As a result, the oxygen extracted by the renal tissues is relatively low compared to the amount of blood flow, resulting in a low A-V O2 difference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain: The brain has a higher arteriovenous oxygen difference due to its significant metabolic activity and oxygen consumption to support its functions. The brain requires a constant and substantial supply of oxygen for neuronal activity, resulting in a higher A-V O2 difference compared to the kidney.

 

Option C. Skin: The skin also has a relatively low oxygen consumption compared to organs like the brain and liver, but its arteriovenous oxygen difference is still higher than that of the kidney. The skin is primarily involved in protective functions and thermoregulation, requiring less oxygen.

 

Option D. Liver: The liver has a moderate to high arteriovenous oxygen difference due to its metabolic functions, including detoxification, synthesis of proteins, and other vital activities that require substantial oxygen consumption. The liver's metabolic demands make its A-V O2 difference higher than that of the kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference among the given organs due to its primary function of blood filtration, which requires relatively low oxygen extraction. This results in a low A-V O2 difference compared to organs like the brain and liver that have higher metabolic and oxygen consumption demands.

questions.text: Which protein is responsible for connecting the Z-lines to the M-lines within a myofibril? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Titin

 

Explanation:

 

Titin is the largest known protein in the human body with a molecular mass of approximately 3,000,000 Da. It plays a critical structural role in the sarcomere by connecting the Z-lines to the M-lines, thereby providing essential scaffolding for the entire sarcomeric structure. Titin also contributes significantly to muscle elasticity through its folded domains that can unfold during initial stretching (providing low resistance) and then offer increasing resistance with further stretch to protect sarcomere integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Kinin: Kinins are inflammatory mediators and not structural proteins of muscle fibers. They have no role in connecting sarcomeric components.
  • Option b. Desmin: While desmin is an important structural protein, it functions by adding structure to the Z-lines through binding them to the plasma membrane. It does not connect Z-lines to M-lines.
  • Option d. Actin: Actin forms the thin filaments of the sarcomere and does not serve as a connecting protein between Z-lines and M-lines. It interacts with myosin during muscle contraction but does not have a structural scaffolding role between these components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Titin functions as a molecular spring providing both elasticity and structural integrity to the sarcomere by forming a continuous filament from Z-line to M-line, making it essential for proper muscle function and sarcomere stability.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Immunoglobulins

 

Explanation

 

Immunoglobulins are produced by plasma cells.

 

Essentially all the albumin and fibrinogen of the plasma proteins, as well as 50 to 80 per cent of the globulins, are formed in the liver. The remainder of the globulins are formed almost entirely in the lymphoid tissues. They are mainly the gamma globulins that constitute the antibodies used in the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Exclusion, as albumin is a major protein synthesized by the liver, which is the most abundant protein in plasma, playing crucial roles in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting substances such as drugs and hormones.

 

Option B. Coagulation factors: Exclusion, as these are primarily produced by the liver, including factors such as prothrombin and fibrinogen.

 

Option C. Acute phase proteins: Exclusion, as the liver significantly ramps up production of these proteins in response to inflammation or infection (like C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A (SAA), which play roles in modulating the immune response and inflammation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

 

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signaling? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin

 

Insulin uses the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling to exert its functions.

 

Insulin receptor is a tetramer, formed by four glycoprotein subunits (two α-subunits and two β-subunits). The α-subunits protrude out of the cell and the β-subunits protrude inside the cell. The α and β subunits are linked to each other by disulfide bonds. Intracellular surfaces of α-subunits have the enzyme activity – protein kinase (tyrosine kinase) activity.

 

When insulin binds with α-subunits of the receptor protein, the tyrosine kinase at the β-subunit (that protrudes into the cell) is activated by means of autophosphorylation.

 

Activated tyrosine kinase acts on many intracellular enzymes by phosphorylating or dephosphorylating them so that some of the enzymes are activated while others are inactivated

 

Other hormones acting in a similar fashion includes

 

  • Growth factors like VEGF, PDGF, FGF, NGF
  • hormones acting via cytokine receptor - Prolactin, Growth hormone

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone): Incorrect. TSH acts through a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), not a receptor tyrosine kinase. It stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones by activating the adenylyl cyclase signaling pathway.

 

Option C. TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone): Incorrect. TRH also utilizes G protein-coupled receptors and primarily influences the pituitary gland to release TSH, using intracellular signaling mechanisms involving phospholipase C.

 

Option D. MSH (Melanocyte-Stimulating Hormone): Incorrect. MSH binds to melanocortin receptors, which are GPCRs, and is involved in a variety of functions including skin pigmentation and appetite regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin uniquely uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling among the options listed, activating complex pathways that are essential for regulating glucose metabolism and other metabolic processes in the body.

questions.text: Which of the following factor is not derived from an ABG analysis directly? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is a critical test in clinical settings that measures the levels of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and the pH of the blood. These parameters are directly measured by the ABG machine. However, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured by the ABG machine; instead, it is calculated using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, which involves the measured pH and PCO2 values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PO2: The partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) is directly measured by the ABG machine, providing vital information about oxygenation status.

 

Option C. PCO2: The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) is also directly measured by the ABG machine and indicates the level of CO2 in the blood, reflecting respiratory function.

 

Option D. pH: The pH level of the blood, which indicates its acidity or alkalinity, is directly measured by the ABG machine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABG analysis measures the levels of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and the pH of the blood, not bicarbonate.

choices.text: Oxidation of Fatty acids
None of the above

questions.text: In a 100-m dash, most of the energy consumed by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP is derived from? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphocreatine

 

Phosphocreatine (also called creatine phosphate) is another chemical compound that has a high-energy phosphate bond. The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds, almost enough for the 100-meter run.
