Thus, the energy from the phosphagen system is used for maximal short bursts of muscle power.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aerobic glycolysis: This process occurs in the mitochondria and is used for longer-duration, lower-intensity exercise. It involves the oxidation of glucose to produce ATP, but it is too slow to meet the immediate energy demands of a 100-meter dash.

 

Option C. Oxidation of Fatty acids: This is a slower process involving the breakdown of fatty acids in the mitochondria to produce ATP. It primarily supports prolonged, steady-state activities rather than short bursts of high-intensity exercise.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as phosphocreatine is the primary source of rapid ATP replenishment during short, high-intensity activities like a 100-meter dash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a 100-meter dash, the primary source of energy for rapidly replenishing ATP in skeletal muscles is the phosphagen system, utilizing phosphocreatine for short bursts of maximal muscle power lasting approximately 8 to 10 seconds.

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of proximal convoluted tubule except: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

The concentration of chloride on the luminal side is more when compared to sodium, glucose, and amino acids.

 

In the first half of the proximal tubule, sodium is reabsorbed by co-transport along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes thus decreasing their concentrations markedly along the length of the proximal tubule. Thus, the solution will have a higher concentration of chloride which is around 105 mEg/L.

 

In the second half of the proximal tubule, sodium gets re-absorbed along with chloride. Higher chloride (approx. 140meq/L) concentration favors its own diffusion from the lumen into the renal interstitial fluid.

 

Proximal tubule’s high permeability to water, increases water reabsorption thus helps in maintaining sodium concentration and total osmolarity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Their concentration decreases significantly due to nearly complete reabsorption.

 

Option B. Glucose: Similarly, glucose concentration decreases significantly because of active reabsorption.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: Its concentration also decreases due to active reabsorption facilitated by carbonic anhydrase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule does not decrease as significantly as amino acids, glucose, and bicarbonate due to the preferential reabsorption of these other solutes in the early segments of the PCT.

choices.text: Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness
Activates locus coeruleus and cause wakefulness
No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep
Activates histamine release and prevents sleep

questions.text: A man habitually consumes coffee before bedtime and claims difficulty in sleep during night. What is the role of caffeine in wakefulness? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness

 

Caffeine is a stimulant that is commonly consumed to reduce fatigue and increase alertness. Its primary mechanism of action in promoting wakefulness is through blocking the action of adenosine, a neurotransmitter in the brain that promotes sleep and relaxation by binding to adenosine receptors. Normally, when adenosine binds to its receptors, it leads to drowsiness and a decrease in nerve cell activity. Caffeine, due to its structural similarity to adenosine, competes for these receptors but does not activate them. Instead, it blocks the action of adenosine, preventing the onset of sleepiness and promoting wakefulness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activates locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness: The locus coeruleus is a nucleus in the brainstem involved in physiological responses to stress and panic, and it is active during REM sleep to help regulate wakefulness. However, caffeine does not directly activate the locus coeruleus to cause wakefulness; instead, its wakefulness-promoting effect is primarily through adenosine receptor blockade.

 

Option C. No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep: This statement is incorrect because caffeine does play a significant role in maintaining wakefulness even if consumed an hour before sleep. Caffeine has a half-life of about 5-6 hours, meaning it remains active in the system for several hours after consumption, potentially leading to difficulty falling asleep.

 

Option D. Activates histamine release and prevents sleep: Histamine is a neurotransmitter involved in wakefulness, but caffeine does not exert its wakefulness-promoting effects through histamine release. The primary mechanism is through blocking adenosine receptors, not activating histamine release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caffeine promotes wakefulness primarily by blocking adenosine receptors in the brain, thereby preventing the sleep-inducing effects of adenosine.

choices.text: Formed by adenylyl cyclase from ATP
Directly binds to nuclear receptors to initiate gene transcription

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding cAMP as a secondary messenger? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Directly binds to nuclear receptors to initiate gene transcription

 

cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate) is a crucial secondary messenger that mediates intracellular hormone responses through specific pathways. When a hormone binds to its G-protein coupled receptor, it activates adenylyl cyclase, which converts ATP to cAMP. cAMP then primarily activates protein kinase A (PKA), which phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to cellular responses. cAMP does not directly bind to nuclear receptors; instead, PKA can phosphorylate transcription factors that then enter the nucleus to regulate gene expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activates protein kinase A: This is correct. cAMP's primary function is to activate PKA by binding to its regulatory subunits, causing the release of catalytic subunits.

 

Option B. Formed by adenylyl cyclase from ATP: This is correct. Adenylyl cyclase catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which is a fundamental step in this signaling pathway.

 

Option D. Can be degraded by phosphodiesterase: This is correct. Phosphodiesterases break down cAMP to 5'-AMP, which is an important mechanism for terminating the signal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the mechanism of cAMP as a secondary messenger, including its synthesis, primary targets, and degradation, while recognizing that it does not directly interact with nuclear receptors but works through protein kinase A-mediated pathways.

questions.text: The factors that can cause a person to drink water due to stimulation of thirst mechanism is/are? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Dehydration, hemorrhage, and prandial drinking: All three can cause increased thirst resulting in water drinking.

 

Option A. Dehydration: Loss of body fluids leads to increased osmolarity, which stimulates osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus, triggering the sensation of thirst.

 

Option B. Hemorrhage: Significant blood loss decreases blood volume and blood pressure, activating the thirst mechanism to restore fluid balance.

 

Option C. Prandial Drinking: Eating triggers signals that activate thirst neurons via SFO (Subfornical Organ) in the brain, prompting the urge to drink. This anticipatory drinking helps facilitate digestion and prevent future dehydration caused by ingested solutes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Oxygen sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors are for which of the following ion? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the carotid and aortic bodies that detect changes in blood oxygen levels. These receptors play a critical role in the respiratory control by responding to hypoxia (low oxygen levels). The oxygen-sensitive channels in these receptors are specifically sensitive to potassium ions (K+). When oxygen levels drop, these potassium channels close, which leads to a series of events: membrane depolarization, calcium influx, and ultimately, the release of neurotransmitters like ATP. This process triggers signals that increase respiratory activity to raise blood oxygen levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Sodium channels are important in many physiological processes, but they are not specifically sensitive to oxygen levels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option C. HCO3-: Bicarbonate ions are involved in acid-base balance and CO2 transport but are not directly involved in the oxygen sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions play roles in various cellular processes, including maintaining osmotic balance, but they are not the primary ions involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary ion involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors is potassium (K+). The closure of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels during hypoxia is a crucial step in the signaling pathway that regulates respiratory response to low oxygen levels.

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point V to point X as shown below. Which of the following happens in stage W compared to stage Y?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Shivering

 

Explanation:

 

In the above scenario, the patient's hypothalamic thermostat has been reset to a higher temperature, hence the body uses methods like shivering to increase the temperature.

 

 

 

Fig: Effects changing the set-point of the hypothalamic temperature

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sweating

 

  • Stage W: Sweating is unlikely in this phase because the body is in the process of heating up to meet the new higher set point. Sweating is a mechanism used to reduce body temperature and would be counterproductive at this stage.
  • Stage Y: Sweating becomes prominent here as the body seeks to dissipate excess heat after reaching or surpassing the set point.

 

Option C. Increased blood flow to the skin

 

  • Stage W: There is typically decreased blood flow to the skin during this phase due to vasoconstriction, which helps to retain heat. Increasing blood flow to the skin would be counterproductive as it would lead to increased heat loss.
  • Stage Y: Increased blood flow to the skin occurs in this phase to facilitate heat loss through the skin, aiding in thermoregulation by cooling the body down.

 

Option D. Inhibition of chemical thermogenesis

 

  • Stage W: There is actually an increase in chemical thermogenesis during this stage. Chemical thermogenesis, including actions such as the metabolic effects of shivering and brown fat activation, helps to generate additional heat.
  • Stage Y: As the body temperature stabilizes or exceeds the set point, there might be a natural reduction in chemical thermogenesis as the need to generate heat reduces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TEMPERATURE REGULATION -

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rectal

 

In the given clinical scenario measuring rectal temperature would be preferred over other methods in a case of suspected hypothermia, especially in a soldier posted in Siachen where the ambient temperature can be extremely low. Rectal temperature is considered the most accurate method for measuring core body temperature because it reflects the temperature of the body's core organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral: Incorrect. Oral temperature measurements can be influenced by ambient temperature and recent oral intake, making them less reliable in extreme conditions.

 

Option C. Infrared tympanic thermometer: Incorrect. While it measures the temperature of the eardrum, which can represent core body temperature, it may not be reliable if not inserted adequately or if there is earwax obstruction.

 

Option D. Axillary: Incorrect. Axillary temperature measurements are less accurate and can be significantly influenced by environmental factors, making them unreliable in cold environments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For accurate measurement of core body temperature in cases of suspected hypothermia, rectal temperature is the preferred method, especially in extreme environmental conditions like those in Siachen.

questions.text: Phase zero in the adjoining image is due to which of the following? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium influx

 

In the nodal tissue, Phase 0 is due to the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, which causes the rapid depolarization of the pacemaker potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium influx: While a slow influx of sodium occurs during the pacemaker potential's initial phase, it is not responsible for the rapid depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option C. Potassium influx: Potassium ions generally move out of the cell during repolarization and do not contribute to the depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option D. Potassium efflux: Potassium efflux occurs mainly during repolarization, which corresponds to phases 3 and 4 in the nodal tissue, not during the depolarization of Phase 0.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nodal tissue, such as the SA node, Phase 0 of the action potential is caused by the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to the rapid depolarization that initiates the action potential.

questions.text: LH surge in the menstrual cycle is because of?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Estradiol

 

  • Estradiol triggers the LH surge in the menstrual cycle. This phenomenon is an example of positive feedback, where an increase in estrogen levels leads to a significant rise in luteinizing hormone (LH) levels. This LH surge is critical for ovulation, occurring about 36 hours before the egg is released from the ovary.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FSH: Incorrect as FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone), while important for follicle growth, does not directly cause the LH surge.

 

Option C. Progesterone: Incorrect because progesterone levels rise post-ovulation and thus are a consequence of the LH surge rather than its cause.

 

Option D. HCG: Incorrect as human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) is involved post-conception and does not trigger the LH surge in the menstrual cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LH surge in the menstrual cycle is because of Estradiol

Increase in estrogen is responsible for increase in LH (Positive feedback)

LH surge - 36 hours before ovulation

LH peak - 8-10 hrs’ before ovulation

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multifocal atrial tachycardia             

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VT is usually regular and wide QRS tachycardia (QRS > 120ms).

 

Option B. P waves usually absent in AF.

 

Option D. Atrial tachycardia is regular narrow QRS tachycardia with fixed morphology of P wave.

 

Note:

 

  • MAT is usually associated with lung disease and occurs secondary to underlying hypoxemia.
  • Treatment is with CCB > BB to slow the atrial, ventricular rate.
  • Cardioversion is ineffective and contraindicated in this rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia is characterized by multiple ectopic atrial activities leading to variable P wave morphologies and an irregular rhythm, often associated with underlying chronic pulmonary conditions. Management focuses on treating the underlying condition and stabilizing the rate with appropriate medications.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/chap 250/7033

choices.text: Heparan sulfate
Collagen Type IV

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Heparan sulfate

 

Explanation

 

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is an essential component of the glomerular filtration barrier.

 

The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is heparan sulfate. As the major determinants of the anionic charge of the GBM, heparan sulfate chains have been thought to impart charge selectivity to the glomerular filtration. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibronectin: While fibronectin is involved in cell adhesion and matrix assembly, it does not primarily contribute to the charge-dependent filtration properties of the GBM.

 

Option C. Collagen Type IV: This type of collagen forms a structural scaffolding in the GBM, providing mechanical strength and stability rather than charge-based selectivity.

 

Option D. Entactin: Also known as nidogen, entactin helps link the network of laminin and collagen IV in the GBM but does not directly influence charge-based filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heparan sulfate is the critical component responsible for the charge-dependent filtration in the glomerular basement membrane. Its negative charge effectively repels similarly charged molecules, preventing their passage into the urine, which is essential for the body's ability to retain vital proteins and other negatively charged substances.

questions.text: Kinesin, dynein and myosin proteins are an example of? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Transport protein


Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are all examples of molecular motor proteins that play critical roles in cellular transport mechanisms.

 

  • Kinesin: This motor protein moves along microtubules in cells, transporting various cellular cargoes, such as organelles, vesicles, and proteins, from the center of the cell (soma) towards the periphery (axon terminal) in an anterograde direction.
  • Dynein: This motor protein also moves along microtubules but in the opposite direction, transporting cargo from the periphery back to the center of the cell in a retrograde direction.
  • Myosin: This motor protein interacts with actin filaments and is involved in a variety of cellular movements, including muscle contraction and intracellular cargo transport.

 

These proteins are not involved in cell membrane structure, adhesion of cell organelles, or forming intercellular junctions. Their primary function is to facilitate intracellular transport, making them key components of cellular logistics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell membrane protein: These are proteins that are part of or interact with the cell membrane, such as receptors and ion channels.

 

Option C. Cell organelle adherent protein: These proteins help maintain the structure and position of organelles within the cell. Ex: catenin and cadherin

 

Option D. Intercellular junctional protein: These are proteins that form connections between cells, such as connexins in gap junctions or occludins in tight junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are transport proteins essential for intracellular cargo movement along cytoskeletal filaments.
